item.description:
Second suppers. You do know about second suppers, don't you? What about third'sies?

As I said, a few of us will be spending the night, either on-trail or in-town, with the intention of continuing our dining experience by consuming a second portion of the Mass-AT on Sunday, more specifically, the second leg of our RI Outdoors Hike The Massachusetts Appalachian Trail Because It’s There Odyssey, and should anyone else be a mutton for punishment, you're welcome to join us.

It all begins in the waning hours of Saturday afternoon as the sun prepares to set and we prepare to depart. For those that choose to stay in-wood, you will find that the Race Brook Falls campsite, just below the AT, provides just the right amount of spice for an overnight. Composed of 4 tent platforms, a bear box, fresh water stream, and privy (what bears call a “people box”), you’ll have all the amenities one could desire to survive the unforgiving wilderness of the Berkshire woods. For those that choose to stay in-town, there are a number of hotels/motels to choose from that provide easy access to mattresses, bathrooms, and hairdryers, & restaurants, coffeehouses and pubs… in short, all the amenities to survive the harsh streets of Great Barrington. Now, should we survive the night, we will plan to meet the following morning, Sunday morning, and begin to feast on the next leg of our journey.


PS: Let’s not forget to give-it-up for our Odysseus (John) for launching this odyssey we’ve so enjoyed.


Also, should the Race Brook Falls campsite not provide suitable shelter from the elements, there are other in-wood options.


The Hike:

Sunday morning, we'll meet at the Shay's Rebellion Monument Parking Lot, car spot and drive back over to Rt 41 and the Race Brook Falls Trailhead. From here, we'll retrace our steps back up Race Brook Falls Trail and reconnect with those of us that camped-out and the AT. RBFT includes several water crossings which can be somewhat challenging, so be prepared for plenty of mud and slippery rocks! Once back on the AT we begin a difficult 0.7 mile ascent to the summit of Mt Everett (2602 ft), the highest point of the weekend, before we hike 3.5 miles north to the rocky summit of Jug End (1705 ft), but only after having crossed several other summits along the way. Good views from the top of Jug End and a steep 1.1 mile descent over rock and root will have us welcoming the final 2.7 miles of our hike. Total hike is 10 miles with an approx. elevation gain of 2100 ft.

 

EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST

Cool Weather/Spring Essentials (required):
• Synthetic Quick-drying Pants
• Synthetic Quick-drying L/S Shirt
• Sturdy Hiking Boots/shoes (preferably waterproof)
• Synthetic/Wool Socks
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket
• Light/Mid-weight Insulating Layers (undershirt/underpants)
• Extra pair of Socks
• Hat/Gloves
• Rain/Soft Shell Jacket/Pants
• Water (2-3L)
• Headlamp/Flashlight
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)


the Remaining Essentials:
• Medications/First Aid Supplies
• Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's hardly a reason not to have one in your pack)
• Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
• Repair Kit/Knife

Optional:
• Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellant/Toiletries
• Light-weight Wind Jacket (if your insulated or rain jacket isn’t windproof)
• Hand Warmers
• Trekking Poles
• Gaiters
• Light-weight Emergency Shelter
• Camera/Binoculars

 

Is This Hike for Me?

This is a lengthy hike over difficult terrain with some decent elevation gains. We will have to move at good pace because of the length of the hike so I ask that only experienced hikers in good physical condition sign up. I'm limiting the numbers on this hike so please only sign up if you are sure you can make it (which really always applies, but its worth calling out). Please bring plenty of water (I'm bringing 2-3 liters) appropriate hiking attire (no jeans or cotton clothing, wear hiking boots not sneakers), rain gear in case the weather turns nasty, lunch, and snacks. Do expect some muddy trails, and certainly don't expect to get out of this one with clean boots!


Route Information:

2 miles on the Race Brook Falls Trail to its junction with the Appalachian Trail.

.7 miles to Mt Everett(2,602 ft). 

1.8 miles to the intersection with Elbow Trail

1.7 miles to Jug End Mountain (1750 ft)

1.1 miles to intersection with Jug End Road

2.7 miles to Shay's Rebellion Monument

 

Trailhead Directions:

From Providence 2 hours 45 minutes

From Newport 3 hours 10 minutes

From MA Turnpike: Take Exit 2 off of Rt 90, follow Rt 102 west to Stockbridge, turning left (south) onto Rt 7 towards Great Barrington, continue south on Rt 7 driving thru Great Barrington for approx. 10.5 miles; turn right onto Lime Kiln Road. Follow Lime Kiln Rd. to Sheffield/Egremont Rd. and turn right. The trailhead parking lot is located on the left just past Shays Rebellion Monument.

Google Maps: http://maps.google.com/maps?saddr=US-20+E%2FHousatonic+St&daddr=Sheffield-Egremont+Rd&hl=en&ll=42.166075,-73.357944&spn=0.076214,0.15089&sll=42.298008,-73.265762&sspn=0.076055,0.1...

Alternate Route: Follow Rt 7 south; turn right onto Rt41-S/Rt23-W toward South Egremont; turn left onto Sheffield/Egremont Rd. before the Rt 41/Rt 23 split; parking is on the right just before Shay's Rebellion Monument.

Coordinates: 42.147133, -73.3866


Carpool Option:

Please use the comments section to coordinate with other hikers if you want to carpool.
